title: Elliott Management Has a More Than $1 Billion Stake in Citrix Systems
summary: Activist hedge fund wants the software company to take steps to boost its valuation. Activist hedge fund Elliott Management Corp. has a more than $1 billion stake in Citrix Systems Inc. and wants the software company to take action to boost its lagging stock price, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Kim Kardashian's Instagram Post on Cryptocurrency Prompts U.K. Financial Watchdog to React
summary: Head of the Financial Conduct Authority criticizes promotion of EthereumMax token. An Instagram post by Kim Kardashian asking her Instagram followers to join "the Ethereum Max Community" is bringing social media's role in promoting cryptocurrency into the spotlight.

title: El Salvador Becomes First Country to Adopt Bitcoin as National Currency
summary: Resume Subscription. SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador-Tiny and impoverished El Salvador's move to become the first country in the world to adopt bitcoin as legal tender got off to a bumpy start, as the government took its bitcoin e-wallet offline for several hours after tens of thousands of people tried to download the app, overloading servers.

title: Doctors Join the Climate Lobby
summary: Don't they know that poverty kills far more people than heat does?. Medical journals are supposed to be forums for doctors to publish research and debate ideas. But like traditional media outlets, many are finding it harder to control their political bias. Now some 200 journal editors are showing their political hand on climate change in an apocalyptic and misleading joint editorial this week that could have been ghost-written by Greta Thunberg.

title: Britain's Tax Warning to America
summary: Boris turns the Tories into tax collectors for the entitlement state.. If Boris Johnson wants to turn the United Kingdom into an economic dynamo after Brexit and the pandemic, he's picked the wrong way to do it. His administration-allegedly conservative-on Tuesday unveiled its second major tax increase this year to fund a new middle-class entitlement.

title: Democrats Are Back to Hating Voter ID
summary: The House passes H.R.4, which would suspend many ID rules.. For about 10 minutes this summer, Democrats pretended that they've never opposed voter-ID laws. How strange, then, to watch 219 House Democrats unite last month to pass H.R.4, a bill that would appear to immediately suspend the voter-ID rules used in maybe a dozen states, possibly more.

title: So This Is a Normal Presidency?
summary: At this point the American people would settle for competency.. Joe Biden was supposed to deliver a return to presidential normalcy, and that may be all he thinks is necessary to satisfy the 81 million voters who elected him. Sooner or later, however, the country will start pining for a return to competency as well, and it's far from clear that this administration is up to the task.

title: What Kabul's Fall Means to the Post-9/11 Generation
summary: Twenty years after the World Trade Center attack, students reflect on the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan and war on terror.. Editor's note: This Future View discusses the American withdrawal from Afghanistan and the war on terror. Next week we'll ask, "What are your thoughts on China's recent decision to ban minors from playing video games during weekday hours?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Sept. 14. The best responses will be published that night.

title: JetBlue Promotes Acting CFO to Permanent Role
summary: Ursula Hurley succeeds Steve Priest, who left the low-cost carrier for eBay. JetBlue Airways Corp. made its interim finance chief permanent, a move that comes after eBay Inc. poached the previous executive in the role.

title: Microsoft Start Allows Users to Create Personalized News Feed
summary: Similar to offerings from Google and Apple, Microsoft's new platform uses content from more than 1,000 publishers. Microsoft Corp. has launched a news feed not unlike those offered by rivals such as Apple.

title: Ford Hires Apple's Doug Field to Advance Technology Role
summary: Executive played role in developing Tesla's Model 3 compact car and has been working on iPhone maker's car project. As Silicon Valley and the Motor City fight for the future of the car, the latest raid took place Tuesday: Ford Motor Co. wooed Doug Field away from Apple Inc. to bolster its own efforts to better integrate software in the automobile.

title: Politicians Who Don't Mind Inflation
summary: How many Americans enjoy automatic protection against declines in real pay?. Institutionally, politicians tend to enjoy inflation because in real terms it allows them to pay back less than promised to buyers of fixed-rate government debt. But there's also a more personal reason why many politicians don't get too exercised about rising prices. Automatic cost-of-living adjustments tend to be more common in government financial arrangements than in private ones. And some of this year's adjustments are bound to be infuriating to taxpayers.

title: Meet the New Taliban, Same as the Old
summary: The cabinet appointment of a terrorist wanted by the FBI is a slap in the face to the U.S. and its allies.. So much for a kinder and more enlightened Taliban. This week, the Taliban announced that Sirajuddin Haqqani-the group's deputy leader and close ally of al Qaeda-will be its first minister of interior. A U.S.-designated terrorist with close ties to the group responsible for 9/11 is now the Afghan equivalent of director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: China Sees Its Nuclear Arsenal as More Than a Deterrent
summary: Beijing is adding warheads, missiles and subs at an alarming rate. The goal is global dominance.. The military threat from Beijing is accelerating at a pace few anticipated. Recently released satellite imagery shows that China is rapidly constructing nearly 300 hardened underground silos in its western desert to house intercontinental ballistic missiles. Also unexpected was the revelation that China recently began work on a third site of similar size near Ordos City that was not previously associated with ICBMs.

title: Chicago's Bloody Past Is Very Present
summary: Bus tours of Al Capone's haunts are popular, but the city's bloodshed makes nostalgia for gangsters a tough sell.. During this bloody summer in Chicago the tour buses, although they have been popular in town for years, couldn't look more jarring as they drive through the streets.

title: Get Ready for the Blackouts
summary: Mismanagement and the push for renewables are degrading the reliability of the U.S. electrical grid.. Generac Power Systems , a company that produces home generators and other equipment, announced in July record sales of $920 million during the second quarter, a 68% jump over last year. But what's good for Generac is bad for America.

title: 'The Authority of the Court and the Peril of Politics' Review: On Judicial Supremacy
summary: In the text of a notable lecture, Justice Stephen Breyer explores judicial power, the rule of law and the role of the judiciary in the American polity.. In the United Kingdom, there is a tradition of printing 100-page books-booklets, really-from lectures given by notable judges and lawyers. The Hamlyn Lecture series, for example, has featured such distinguished talks as Lord Denning's "Freedom Under the Law" (1949), Professor Arthur Goodhart's "English Law and the Moral Law" (1953) and Dean Erwin Griswold's "Law and Lawyers in the United States" (1964). The primers are collectible, memorable and quotable.

title: Is Donald Trump Finished?
summary: Admit it: You don't want him to run again yet his absence hasn't solved any problem.. Is Donald Trump playing the game badly? The question needs to be asked. If you think Mr. Trump the worst thing that ever happened to America, the answer might not be entirely reassuring.

title: Biden Tours Northeastern States Hammered by Ida
summary: President argues for federal investment to help communities better endure major storms. WASHINGTON-President Biden used a trip to parts of the Northeast battered by the remnants of Hurricane Ida to press his case for the importance of federal investment to help communities better endure major storms.

title: Marsh & McLennan Appoints Dedicated Compliance Chief
summary: The professional services company now has a dedicated chief compliance officer after their former deputy general counsel, who also oversaw compliance, took up a position in its brokerage business. Marsh & McLennan Cos. has appointed a dedicated compliance chief following the promotion of the professional services company's deputy general counsel, who had previously overseen the function.

title: Firefighters Gain Ground on Caldor Fire, Dixie Fire
summary: Officials warn season is far from over as fall predicted to be dry and windy. Firefighters made progress on two of California's largest blazes over the weekend as the region moves into the middle of fire season and exhausted crews look ahead to busy months.

title: Should Ransomware Payments Be Made Illegal?
summary: Proponents say it would lead to fewer attacks. Opponents say that organizations need the option to pay. The two sides square off in a debate.. It's a nightmare scenario. A company gets a notice telling them that hackers have broken into their network and encrypted their data. If the company wants the information back, they need to pay a ransom-or potentially face ruin.

title: Stocks Finish Mixed After Long-Weekend Break
summary: S&P 500 retreats from recent record. U.S. stocks fell with the S&P 500 in the red Tuesday as investors worried that the spread of Covid-19 will weigh on economic growth.

title: Intel to Invest Up to $95 Billion in European Chip-Making Amid U.S. Expansion
summary: Semiconductor maker pledges to dedicate production capacity in Ireland to car chips to help mitigate shortages. Intel Corp. plans to build new chip-making facilities in Europe valued at up to $95 billion, responding to a cross-border race to add manufacturing capacity at a time of a global chip-supply crunch.

title: The Best Way to Stop Ransomware Attacks: Be Proactive, Not Reactive
summary: The Justice Department needs to investigate and prosecute the crime organizations that support these attacks. Whenever the Justice Department has confronted a new and sophisticated criminal threat, it has focused its resources on proactive rather than reactive investigations and reorganized itself accordingly. That's how the department confronted organized crime in the 1960s, and terrorists after Sept. 11. And that is how the department should confront ransomware today.

title: U.S. Probes Examine Raytheon's Dealings With Qatari Defense Contractor
summary: Antibribery probes were sparked by a lawsuit in California involving the Qatari military, according to people familiar with the matter. U.S. authorities are investigating whether payments by Raytheon Technologies Corp. to a consultant for the Qatar Armed Forces may have been bribes intended for a member of the country's ruling royal family, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Unscripted (Wednesday Crossword, September 8)
How Hackers Use Our Brains Against Us
summary: Cybercriminals take advantage of the unconscious processes that we all use to make decision making more efficient. Blame it on our 'lizard brains.'. The email from the boss asking to transfer money to a new supplier. The link sent from a client, but whose return email address is slightly off. The request from somebody in the IT department asking for system login information.

title: Texas Voting Law: What You Need to Know
summary: The law fiercely opposed by Democrats adds ID requirements and bans 24-hour voting but also increases minimum early voting hours. Republican lawmakers in Texas have passed a broad set of election-law changes, overcoming efforts to delay the legislation by Democrats. The new law tightening voting procedures represents the latest in a string of new state voting-law changes this year.

title: Taliban Unveil New Afghan Government
summary: Afghanistan's new rulers omit other political forces and women, give senior post to leader of al Qaeda-linked group. KABUL-Four days before the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks that triggered the U.S. invasion of Afghanistan, the Taliban declared the restoration of their Islamic Emirate and named a new government, excluding other political forces and giving control of internal security to a U.S.-designated terrorist.

title: Dallas Fed's Robert Kaplan Was Active Buyer and Seller of Stocks Last Year
summary: Eleven of the Fed's 12 regional banks have provided disclosures of their leaders' 2020 financial profiles in recent days. Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan made multiple million-dollar-plus stock trades in 2020, according to a financial disclosure form provided by his bank, in contrast with other regional Fed leaders who reported more modest financial holdings and smaller transactions.

title: How Would a 'Green' Economy Weather Hurricane Ida?
summary: Wishful thinking and feel-good politics didn't keep the Mississippi river and Lake Pontchartrain from overflowing.. Thank goodness we still have gasoline and gasoline-powered vehicles in Louisiana ("Hurricane Ida's Resilience Lesson," Review & Outlook, Aug. 31). I cannot imagine evacuating with an electric vehicle, driving through deep water with an EV or charging it during a power outage, like we have in southern Louisiana. If you're out of gas, it's possible to refuel, but how would you recharge on the side of the interstate? And all those generators can't be run on batteries. Sometimes reality is a wake-up call.

title: U.S. Withdraws, but the Terrorists Fight On
summary: The war hasn't ended. It has become more dangerous.. Regarding "America's Longest War Ends" (Page One, Aug. 31): The war with al Qaeda and Islamic extremists began before the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks (e.g., the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, the 1998 embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania and the attack on the USS Cole in 2000). Despite warnings from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Central Intelligence Agency, it took 9/11 for administrations and politicians to focus on al Qaeda, which was protected by the Taliban in Afghanistan. For the past 20 years and with many sacrifices by the U.S. military, al Qaeda and the Taliban were, if not defeated, at least neutralized, and significant gains and liberties were achieved for the Afghan people. Now the battlefield will shift from their lands to ours once again.

title: The Latest Cybersecurity Threat: Pay Us or We Release the Data
summary: These attacks are a lot more complicated-and potentially more costly.

title: Does the Constitution Let Congress Pass a Wealth Tax?
summary: It depends what constitutes income.. I'm sympathetic to the argument of David B. Rivkin Jr. and Andrew M. Grossman that Congress can't avoid constitutional problems with a wealth tax by calling it an income tax ("Can Congress Tax Wealth by 'Deeming' It Income?" op-ed, Sept. 2), but the authors overstate their case in one respect.

title: The Murky Next Stage in Human Evolution
summary: The potential for tragedy is enormous.. H.G. Wells's fictional vision of human evolution in "The Time Machine" (1895) is a bifurcation of our species 800,000 years in the future. Wells was much more accurate about the direction of our evolution than about the timeline. In "Imagine a Future Without Sex" (op-ed, Sept. 1), James Lee explains how current "reproductive technology" can be used to screen embryos for higher intelligence prior to in-vitro fertilization.

title: Intel's Salvation Lies in Europe-but Not With Fabs
summary: Chip giant needs prime access to cutting-edge tools from ASML to close its manufacturing gap with TSMC. Intel Corp. may be planning on pouring billions into Europe, but the chip-making giant's investment in the Continent is unlikely to end there.

title: Bitcoin Price Tumbles After El Salvador Makes It National Currency
summary: The world's largest cryptocurrency falls as much as 17% on 'Bitcoin Day'. Bitcoin gave El Salvador a taste of its famous volatility on Tuesday, as the Central American country became the first nation in the world to adopt the asset as a national currency.

title: New Apple iPhone Expected to Be Unveiled at Sept. 14 Event
summary: After relatively significant upgrades last year, analysts are expecting more incremental changes for 2021. Apple Inc. scheduled an event for Sept. 14, called "California Streaming," at which the company is expected to unveil its latest line of iPhones.

title: AMC's Theater Chain Sets U.S. Labor Day Weekend Record
summary: Marvel's superhero movie 'Shang-Chi' helped to boost attendance figures. Marvel Studios' "Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings" had a record debut that drove the best Labor Day weekend attendance figures at AMC Theatres , the chain's parent company said Tuesday.

title: In Elizabeth Holmes's Trial, Prosecutors Must Show Intent
summary: Convincing a jury that the founder willfully misled investors could be difficult, as many startups make sincere efforts to deliver on promises yet fail. Silicon Valley startups are often perceived to be walking a line between exaggeration and deception in promoting their products. Federal prosecutors trying Theranos Inc. founder Elizabeth Holmes in California must convince a jury that she didn't believe her own hype.

title: Biden Needs a Win on Infrastructure
summary: Getting progressives to accept less than what they want will be a tall order.. August was a month of disasters for Joe Biden. September will be a month of decisions-big ones-about his domestic policy agenda.

title: Texas Governor Signs Divisive Voting Bill Into Law
summary: Governor, Republicans say bill will improve election security; Democrats say it is aimed at suppressing votes. Texas Gov. Greg Abbott signed into law a Republican-backed bill tightening voting rules, as voting activists mobilize to fight the legislation with lawsuits.

title: Marvin Miller Belongs in Cooperstown
summary: Today's well-paid baseball stars should tip their caps to the late union boss.. Marvin Miller, who led the Major League Baseball Players Association from 1966 to 1982, is being inducted this week into the baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y. Not long before he died in 2012, Marvin called to tell me he was seriously ill and wanted his friends to know he was at peace with what lay ahead. He was unique. So was that call.

title: U.K. Is Among First Western Nations to Increase Taxes to Cover Covid-19 Costs
summary: Johnson government will raise payroll taxes to help support a state-funded healthcare system that is struggling to manage the aftermath of the pandemic. LONDON-British Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced tax increases to support the country's state-funded National Health Service as it struggles to manage a backlog of millions of patients in the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Deutsche Telekom's Deal With SoftBank Tightens Grip on T-Mobile
summary: Share swap deal will give Japanese investor a stake in German company. Deutsche Telekom AG is speeding up its efforts to retake a majority stake in T-Mobile US Inc. through a complex transaction with SoftBank Group Corp.

title: State Street to Buy Brown Brothers' Investor-Services Business
summary: Deal is bank's largest since it bought Charles River three years ago. State Street Corp. agreed to buy Brown Brothers Harriman & Co.'s investor-services unit for $3.5 billion in cash, a deal that expands the custody bank's core business serving investment firms.

title: Tips to Get the Best Performance From an Older iPhone
summary: To rejuvenate your increasingly vintage model, check its battery health, free up storage and weigh your repair options. New iPhones are just around the corner-we expect them to appear on Sept.14, in Apple's just-announced streamed news event-but before you rush to buy one of the new ones, take a closer look at the one you've got.

title: Wells Fargo Isn't Missing the Party Yet
summary: Shares of the big bank were hit by fresh Washington worries, but the stock's strong performance this year is more rooted in the rate environment. Investors have closely linked Wells Fargo's fortunes to regulators ever since its fake-account scandal broke into public view several years ago. They may want to think bigger.

title: These Sensor-Studded Smart Clothes Just Might Save Your Life
summary: From a prescription bra that signals cardiac arrest to a mosquito-proof textile, startups and scientists are developing garments for healthier living. Author

title: Corey Stoll Didn't Land 'Romeo Roles'-So He Worked Toward Something Bigger
summary: Resume Subscription. Corey Stoll, 45, is an actor who appeared in the TV series "House of Cards" and in the films "Midnight in Paris" and "First Man." He co-stars in the Showtime series "Billions" and in the film "The Many Saints of Newark." He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: U.S. Economy Faces Slowdown Just as It Was Set to Take Off
summary: Resume Subscription. The U.S. economy is facing a slowdown in September, rather than the takeoff once hoped for.

title: Banana Republic Tries to Become Cool Again-By Looking to Its Past
summary: With the launch of its latest collection today, Banana Republic aims to marry the adventurous safari look of its '80s and '90s clothing with the safe, white-collar style it has pushed over the past decade.. On its e-commerce site this June, Banana Republic launched the BR Vintage collection: 225 items from the company's safari-style past, including khaki shirts, lengthy suede jackets and multi-pocket photojournalist vests. The brand amassed the clothes-mostly dating to the 1980s and '90s-with the aid of Thrilling and the Society Archive, two startups that source vintage clothes from sellers around the country. At $229 for a pair of leather-and-linen women's boots and $498 for a men's leather flight jacket, prices exceeded what vintage Banana pieces sell for on resale sites like eBay and Depop, but weren't far off the designs' original retail prices. Within the first day, 50% of the items had sold.

title: How 9/11 Changed Pop Culture in America
summary: Resume Subscription. Wishful thinking is a chronic affliction of pundits on a deadline. I suspect that I was suffering from a slight case of it when, four months after 9/11, I wrote a column for The Wall Street Journal called "Tawdriness in Turnaround." Struck by the fact that Diana Krall's "The Look of Love," an album of traditional pop standards, was the eighth biggest-selling CD of any genre on Amazon.com-I had just heard the title track playing in a McDonald's on New York's Upper West Side-I speculated that the horrors of that day had awakened in Americans an appetite for straightforward, unironic beauty. "What we wanted in our time of need," I wrote, "was beauty-and we never doubted for a moment that such a thing exists."

title: Chinese Authorities Drop Case Against Former Alibaba Manager Accused of Sexual Assault
summary: Fired executive is subjected to 15 days of detention for forcible indecency. TAIPEI-Chinese authorities said the actions of a manager with e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. accused of sexually assaulting a co-worker didn't rise to the level of a crime, dropping a case that had drawn widespread public attention and sent Chinese tech companies scrambling to implement sexual-harassment policies.

title: Blackstone to Buy Chamberlain Group
summary: Deal values family-owned maker of garage-door openers at about $5 billion. Blackstone Group Inc. has agreed to buy the Chamberlain Group LLC in a deal that values the family-owned maker of LiftMaster garage-door openers at about $5 billion including debt, officials from the companies said.

title: Toyota and BMW Are Auto Industry's Contrarian Investors
summary: Chasing after Tesla isn't the only way for car makers to cut carbon emissions. Toyota and BMW aren't telling Tesla-obsessed investors what they want to hear about electric vehicles. Investors may be the ones who need to change.

title: Virtual Reality Puts Drug Researchers Inside the Molecules They Study
summary: The immersive technology reveals clues about how compounds might work, with the aim of speeding up the drug-discovery process. Author

title: Bitcoin, Match, Spotify: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: The cryptocurrency is ticking lower on the day it becomes an official currency in El Salvador. U.S. stock futures wobbled, suggesting that the S&P 500 will hover close to its record at the opening bell following the long holiday weekend. Here's what we're watching before Tuesday's trading heats up.

title: Toyota to Spend $9 Billion on Electric-Car Battery Plants
summary: Japanese car maker, late to the electric-vehicle race, accelerates plans as sales grow. TOKYO- Toyota Motor Corp. said it would spend $9 billion over the next decade to build factories for electric-car batteries as it gears up to sell two million electric cars annually by the end of the decade.

title: 9/11 Changed Flying for Good-to Some Travelers' Chagrin
summary: Resume Subscription. Flying changed the morning of Sept. 11, 2001-for travelers and the airline industry alike.

title: As Tech Industry Seeks Bigger Defense Role, Some Are Leery
summary: Ex-Google CEO Eric Schmidt says the U.S. is in danger of losing its military edge if it doesn't join forces with Silicon Valley. WASHINGTON-Tech-industry leaders are pushing the Pentagon to adopt commercially developed technologies on a grand scale to counter the rise of China, an initiative that could transform the military and the multibillion-dollar defense-contracting business.

title: Is This (Finally) the Season of the Buffalo Bills?
summary: The NFL kicks off its longest-ever campaign Thursday. Tom Brady's going to be Tom Brady. But could Josh Allen deliver a historic title to Western New York?. Seventeen games. Start there. It's a lot. Prepare your snack drawer accordingly. The 2021 NFL season begins Thursday, with the defending Super Bowl champion Tampa Bay Buccaneers hosting the NFC East's defending third-place calamity, the Dallas Cowboys, and I'm telling you right now: This is going to be a long journey. Pace yourselves. Get plenty of sleep. Nap. Stretch. As Tampa's 64-year-old quarterback, Tom Brady, would surely advise: hydrate.

title: What's Really Driving the Sally Rooney Obsession?
summary: The bestselling novelist swiftly moved from literary darling to the mainstream. What made her such a star? With her new novel, 'Beautiful World, Where Are You,' can she keep it up?. In 2016, when Mitzi Angel, then publisher at Faber in London, first came across the manuscript of Sally Rooney's debut novel, Conversations With Friends, she was not envisioning bestseller lists and television adaptations. She was not imagining that Rooney's future books would be compared to luxury handbags in Vanity Fair or that people would be scrambling to get their hands on her galleys. She did notice the young people around the office starting to talk about the characters as if they were real people.

title: What if China's Property Crackdown Goes Overboard Too?
summary: The escalating pressure on tech draws attention, but the bigger risk is that the new regulatory enthusiasm tips over a more familiar target. China's regulatory crackdown has wiped billions off technology companies' market value. But the continuing squeeze on real estate-if allowed to run much further-could have even bigger repercussions.

title: Big Aerospace Contractors Bet On Space Refueling Startup
summary: Northrop Grumman and Lockheed Martin have invested in startup Orbit Fab. Northrop Grumman Corp. and Lockheed Martin Corp. have invested in a spacecraft refueling startup, deepening the aerospace industry's investment in space-based services.

title: China's Educational Crackdown Hits Apartment Prices in Its Biggest Cities
summary: Beijing's attempts to delink educational opportunity from home location is hitting a once-booming corner of the property market. BEIJING-The market for what had been some of the most desirable apartments in China's biggest and wealthiest cities has seized up, as Beijing intensifies a campaign to open access to education.

title: Schools Use Covid-19 Tests to Keep Students Out of Quarantine
summary: Certain districts offer near-daily testing to avoid sending children home after exposure to known cases. Some schools are trying a new plan to keep students safely in the classroom: Rather than quarantining children who have an in-school contact with a positive case, they are testing them. A lot.

title: Property Investors Look to College Housing
summary: Companies are pumping billions of dollars into buying and developing off-campus housing. With millions of students heading back to college campuses this month, some of the world's largest property investors are pumping billions of dollars into buying and developing off-campus housing.

title: Office Occupancy Sputtered in August as Delta Variant Foiled Return-to-Work Hopes
summary: Rise in Covid-19 cases upended calculations that office towers would fill up after Labor Day. Workers in big city business districts are ending the summer back home or at other remote locations, as momentum to return to the office in the spring and early summer mostly petered out in August.

title: Japan Prime Minister Contender Takes Harder Line on Missile-Strike Ability
summary: Fumio Kishida, a former foreign minister, says in an interview that Asia is the front line of the clash between democracies and dictatorships. TOKYO-Japan needs to consider building a missile-strike capability against potential foes, including China and North Korea, said one of the two top candidates to become the nation's next leader, former Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida.

title: Apple Likely Has More App Store Deals to Make
summary: Changes so far won't cause much pain for the tech giant, but loss of payment exclusivity still possible. As Apple Inc. works to negotiate its way out of its App Store troubles, one thing is becoming increasingly clear: The technology titan might have to start competing on its own playing field.

title: A Comeback of the First-Time Venture Fund? Stay Tuned
summary: It's still just a sliver of the market. But torrid returns and a pandemic moment of possibility are spurring more people to launch their own venture firms, with women and diverse investors making inroads. For years, first-time venture fundraising in the U.S. has been on the decline. This year, it's on track to reverse course.

title: Stack Overflow Names New CFO After Prosus Deal
summary: Matt Gallatin joins the online community for software developers as finance chief. Stack Overflow, an online community for software developers, named Matt Gallatin as chief financial officer after it was acquired by European tech giant Prosus NV for $1.8 billion last month.

title: More Russian Companies Set to Join New York IPO Frenzy
summary: Health-food provider VkusVill and SPB Exchange are preparing for U.S. share offerings in coming months. MOSCOW-Health-food provider JSC VkusVill and stock exchange PJSC SPB Exchange are preparing for initial public offerings in the U.S. this year or early next, according to people familiar with the companies, the latest in a string of Russian corporations joining the global IPO rush.

title: U.S. Working With Taliban to Fly Americans Out of Afghanistan
summary: Washington sees safe passage as a first step to rolling back sanctions on a Taliban-led government. DOHA, Qatar-Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the U.S. is negotiating with the Taliban on resolving issues that are preventing American citizens and vulnerable Afghans from leaving Afghanistan through charter flights, while other countries are working to open the airport in Kabul for international flights within days.

title: After the 9/11 Attacks, Wall Street Bolstered Its Defenses
summary: Resume Subscription. The nearly weeklong stock-market shutdown that followed the Sept. 11 attacks seems unimaginable in today's world of round-the-clock trading.

title: Streaming Loosens Nielsen's Grip Over TV Ratings
summary: Company faces a double whammy: challenges in its legacy products and customers looking for alternative ways to measure streaming viewership. TV ratings company Nielsen has been the behemoth in its field for decades, but the shift toward streaming is disrupting its business model and prompting buyers and sellers of ads to look at alternatives.

title: Wall Street Can't Get Enough Fixer-Upper Houses
summary: Resume Subscription. Wall Street has made a mountain of money available to house flippers, and selling move-in-ready rehabs has rarely been easier. The challenge is finding beat-up and out-of-date properties that can be renovated and resold for a profit.

title: How Office Culture Changed in the Pandemic
summary: Most Popular News. A year and a half into the pandemic, many workers have yet to return to offices. But plenty others have been coming in since the early days of Covid-19-and they have much to say about what to expect.

title: Deals Spree Puts Banks on Track for Busiest-Ever Year
summary: In the first eight months of 2021, companies have announced deals worth more than $1.8 trillion in the U.S.. Takeovers are taking over.

title: China's Exports Strengthen, Despite Covid-19 Disruptions
summary: August data show shipments of appliances, furniture and clothing grew, helping offset waning demand for pandemic-related goods. BEIJING-China's exports unexpectedly expanded at a faster clip in August, shrugging off the impact of a global resurgence of the coronavirus pandemic, port congestion and supply bottlenecks.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: How to Estimate a Future Rate of Return on Your Retirement Savings
summary: Retirement calculators ask for that crucial number. Here's how to come up with one.. I'm approaching retirement, and I'm using several online calculators to see how my nest egg might hold up. Each tool asks me to enter a "rate of return" on my investments. What's a reasonable number? How do you figure out what your savings might earn in the future?

title: Actor Michael K. Williams, Who Played Omar on 'The Wire,' Dead at 54
summary: His death is being investigated as a possible drug overdose, the New York Police Department says. NEW YORK-Actor Michael K. Williams, who as the rogue robber of drug dealers Omar Little on "The Wire" created one of the most beloved and enduring characters in a prime era of television, died Monday.
